choices.text: Midsystolic click followed by late systolic murmur
Histology shows fibrinoid necrosis with collagen degeneration

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic finding in a patient with mitral valve prolapse?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is a common valvular abnormality defined by billowing of one or both mitral leaflets into the left atrium during systole, most commonly due to myxomatous degeneration of the valve.

  • On auscultation, the hallmark clinical finding is a mid-systolic click due to sudden tensing of the redundant valve leaflet, followed by a late systolic murmur of mitral regurgitation. This is best heard at the apex and may become more prominent with maneuvers that decrease preload (e.g., standing, Valsalva).
  • MVP has a familial association, often with autosomal dominant inheritance, especially in connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. (Option B ruled out)
  • Histologically, the valve demonstrates myxoid (mucoid) degeneration, not fibrinoid necrosis. This involves accumulation of acid mucopolysaccharides in the spongiosa layer of the valve. (Option C ruled out)
  • Most patients are asymptomatic, and prognosis is generally benign. Complications include mitral regurgitation, infective endocarditis, arrhythmias, and very rarely, sudden cardiac death-especially in individuals with complex ventricular arrhythmias or severe leaflet redundancy. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a described association for Mitral valve prolapse?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Noonan syndrome is typically associated with pulmonary valve stenosis (especially peripheral), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and ASD. It is not classically associated with MVP.

Syndromic associations of MVP include:

  • Marfan syndrome (Option C ruled out)
  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
  • Klinefelter syndrome (Option B ruled out)
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
  • Pseudoxanthoma elasticum

Barlow syndrome is simply another term for classic mitral valve prolapse with redundant, thickened leaflets and myxomatous degeneration. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major criterion in the diagnosis of Rheumatic fever based on Revised Jones criteria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prolonged PR interval is a minor criterion, not a major one.

Low-Risk Population:

  • Defined as <2 cases of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) per 100,000 school-aged children (5-14 years) per year OR
  • <1 in 1000 all-age population prevalence of rheumatic heart disease (RHD)

Common in developed countries and well-resourced urban settings.

Moderate- to High-Risk Populations:

  • Defined as areas with: ≥2 per 100,000 ARF incidence in school-aged children annually OR
  • ≥1 in 1000 all-age population prevalence of RHD
  • Includes many developing regions, rural areas, and indigenous populations

choices.text: Late peaking of ejection systolic murmur

questions.text: All of the following are indicative of the severity of Aortic Stenosis except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wide splitting of S2 is not associated with aortic stenosis (AS).

  • Wide splitting of S2 typically occurs when pulmonary valve closure is delayed, such as in right bundle branch block (RBBB) or pulmonary hypertension.
  • In contrast, aortic stenosis leads to delayed aortic valve closure, causing paradoxical (reversed) splitting, not wide splitting. (Option B ruled out)

choices.text: Age-related valve degeneration is the most common
Typical triad of features includes angina, syncope and dyspnea
Combined aortic stenosis and regurgitation result in pulsus bisferiens
Heyde syndrome is the coexistence of angiodysplasia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in patients with AS

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Aortic stenosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Heyde syndrome is not associated with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Instead, it refers to the triad of:

  • Aortic stenosis
  • Gastrointestinal angiodysplasia (commonly in the colon)
  • Acquired von Willebrand disease type 2A, due to high shear stress causing proteolysis of vWF multimers → leading to bleeding tendency, especially GI bleed

Aortic stenosis (AS) is a common valvular lesion, especially in the elderly, with a progressive, calcific degeneration of the aortic valve being the most common cause in individuals >65 years. In younger patients, it is often due to congenital bicuspid aortic valve. (Option A ruled out)

Classic clinical features of severe AS include the triad: (Option B ruled out)

  • Angina (due to increased myocardial oxygen demand and decreased supply)
  • Syncope (often exertional, due to fixed cardiac output)
  • Dyspnea/Heart failure (due to elevated left ventricular end-diastolic pressure)

Pulsus bisferiens is a biphasic pulse with two systolic peaks and is classically seen in:

  • Combined aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation (Option C ruled out)
  • Severe isolated AR
  • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM)

questions.text: Which of the following features on clinical examination suggests the presence of combined mitral regurgitation and mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mitral stenosis (MS) is a pressure overload condition of the left atrium, not the left ventricle, and thus it does not cause left ventricular (LV) enlargement or a displaced apex beat.

However, when MR coexists with MS (i.e., mixed mitral valve disease), the volume overload from regurgitant flow into the LV leads to LV dilatation. This results in a displaced, diffuse, hyperdynamic apex beat, which is not seen in isolated MS. Therefore, the presence of a displaced apex beat is a strong clinical clue toward MR involvement.

In contrast, isolated MS typically presents with:

  • A localized, tapping apex beat (due to palpable S1 or loud first heart sound) (Option D ruled out)
  • Atrial fibrillation (from LA dilatation and fibrosis) (Option B ruled out)
  • Raised JVP (in advanced cases due to pulmonary hypertension → right heart failure) (Option C ruled out)

The complications observed in advanced MS include

  • Pulmonary artery hypertension
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy and failure

choices.text: Presence of new valvular regurgitation is a major criteria
Osler nodes and Janeway lesions are included under minor criteria
Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive
Presence of 1 major + 2 minor is definitive of diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the Modified Duke Criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnosis of infective endocarditis by Duke's criteria requires either clinical or pathological criteria to be met.

  • If clinical criteria are used, definitive IE is denoted by the presence of 2 major (or) 1 major + 3 minor (or) 5 minor criteria
  • Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis

Clinical Criteria:

Pathological Criteria:

  1. Microorganisms demonstrated by culture or histologic examination, in vegetation, embolus from vegetation or intracardiac abscess OR
  2. Histologic confirmation of active endocarditis in vegetation or intracardiac abscess

questions.text: Which one of the following is the strongest risk factor for developing infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The strongest risk factor for infective endocarditis (IE) is a prior history of IE. This is due to residual endothelial damage and fibrosis that provide an ideal substrate for bacterial colonization. Patients with a history of IE have the highest likelihood of recurrence, even more than those with prosthetic valves or structural heart disease.

Other significant but less strong risk factors include:

  • Rheumatic heart disease: Especially with residual mitral or aortic valve damage (Option C ruled out)
  • Prosthetic heart valves
  • Intravenous drug use: associated with acute right-sided endocarditis, especially involving the tricuspid valve and caused frequently by S. aureus (Option B ruled out)
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Central venous lines: Important in nosocomial IE, especially in ICU and dialysis patients. (Option D ruled out)

Causative organisms and risk associations:

  • Streptococcus viridans (most common cause - 40-50%)
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis (especially prosthetic valves)
  • Staphylococcus aureus (especially acute presentation, IVDUs)
  • Streptococcus bovisis associated with colorectal cancer
  • Non-infective: systemic lupus erythematosus (Libman-Sacks)

Malignancy: Marantic endocarditis

Culture-negative causes

  • Prior antibiotic therapy
  • Coxiella burnetii
  • Bartonella
  • Brucella
  • HACEK: Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella)

Following prosthetic valve surgery, Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common organism in the first 2 months and is usually the result of perioperative contamination.

After 2 months, the spectrum of organisms which cause endocarditis returns to normal, except with a slight increase in Staph. aureus infections.

choices.text: Warfarin with a target INR of 2.0-3.0

questions.text: A 72-year-old man who had a bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement three years ago is reviewed. What antithrombotic therapy is he likely to be taking?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In patients with bioprosthetic (biological) heart valves, the risk of thrombosis is significantly lower than with mechanical valves, especially beyond the initial post-operative period.

  • For aortic bioprosthetic valves, long-term anticoagulation is not usually required. After the initial 3-month postoperative period, low-dose aspirin is recommended as the preferred antithrombotic agent for long-term therapy to reduce the risk of thromboembolism. (Option A ruled out)
  • This is particularly relevant in elderly patients, who are at higher bleeding risk, making aspirin monotherapy preferable.

In contrast:

  • Mechanical valves have a high thrombogenic potential → require lifelong anticoagulation with warfarin, typically targeting an INR of 2.0-3.0 (aortic) or 5-3.5 (mitral), often with adjunct low-dose aspirin unless contraindicated. (Options C & D ruled out)

Prosthetic heart valves:

The most common valves that need replacing are the aortic and mitral valves. There are two main options for replacement: Biological (bioprosthetic) or Mechanical.

Key Takeaway:

Prosthetic heart valves require antithrombotic therapy.

  • Bioprosthetic: Aspirin
  • Mechanical: Warfarin + Aspirin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature associated with acute aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Waterhammer pulse, also known as Corrigan's pulse, is a bounding peripheral pulse with a rapid upstroke and quick collapse due to wide pulse pressure. This is characteristic of chronic aortic regurgitation, where the left ventricle has had time to undergo compensatory eccentric hypertrophy and handle the regurgitant volume, leading to a high stroke volume and widened pulse pressure.

In acute aortic regurgitation (AR),

  • The left ventricle has no time to adapt to the sudden volume overload.
  • This leads to elevated left ventricular end-diastolic pressure, increased left atrial pressure, and pulmonary congestion, manifesting as orthopnea and cyanosis. (Options B & C ruled out)
  • Hypotension is common due to a sharp fall in forward stroke volume, and cardiogenic shock may ensue. (Option A ruled out)
  • The peripheral signs seen in chronic AR (e.g., waterhammer pulse, Quincke's sign, Corrigan's sign, De Musset's sign, wide pulse pressure) are absent in acute AR because stroke volume is reduced, not elevated.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with shortness of breath on exertion. On examination, his blood pressure is 132/60 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min and regular. Auscultation of the chest reveals an early diastolic murmur. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with this type of murmur?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of an early diastolic murmur, especially in the context of widened pulse pressure (BP 132/60 mmHg), is highly suggestive of aortic regurgitation (AR). This murmur is best heard at the left sternal border with the patient leaning forward and during held expiration. It occurs due to regurgitant blood flow from the aorta into the left ventricle during early diastole.

Murmur classification by timing and key causes:

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac conditions is not associated with a continuous murmur?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A continuous murmur is defined as one that begins in systole and continues without interruption through the second heart sound into all or part of diastole. These murmurs typically result from abnormal communications between high-pressure and low-pressure chambers or vessels that persist throughout the cardiac cycle.

MR with AS is not associated with a continuous murmur because,

  • MR causes a holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex and radiating to the axilla.
  • AS produces a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border.
  • When MR and AS coexist, they result in two separate systolic murmurs, but not a continuous murmur, as there is no diastolic component.

questions.text: Which one of the following is least associated with aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Williams syndrome is a genetic disorder associated with supravalvular aortic stenosis, not aortic regurgitation.

Aortic Regurgitation - Features:

  • Early diastolic murmur
  • Collapsing pulse
  • Wide pulse pressure
  • Mid-diastolic Austin-Flint murmur in severe AR - due to partial closure of the anterior mitral valve cusps caused by the regurgitation streams

Causes (due to valve disease)

  • Rheumatic fever (Option A ruled out)
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Connective tissue diseases, e.g. RA/SLE
  • Bicuspid aortic valve (Option D ruled out)

Causes (due to aortic root disease)

  • Aortic dissection
  • Spondylarthropathies (e.g. ankylosing spondylitis)
  • Hypertension
  • Syphilis (Option C ruled out)
  • Marfan's, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome

choices.text: Oral penicillin V is as effective as Benzathine penicillin for secondary prophylaxis
Mitral regurgitation is the most common lesion in acute rheumatic fever
Rheumatic fever without carditis should receive prophylaxis for 5 years or till 21 years of age
The diagnostic criteria for rheumatic fever is different for low and high-risk populations

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding rheumatic fever except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units IM every 4 weeks) is the most effective regimen for secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever.

Oral penicillin V, though effective when taken properly, has lower compliance and efficacy due to daily dosing requirements.

In penicillin-allergic patients, alternatives include erythromycin 250 mg twice daily.

Explanation of Other Options:

Options B, C & D are true

  • In acute rheumatic fever (ARF), mitral regurgitation (MR) is the most frequent valvular lesion due to valvulitis. (Option B ruled out)
  • In contrast, mitral stenosis (MS) becomes more common in chronic rheumatic heart disease after years of fibrosis.
  • Duration of prophylaxis depends on whether carditis was present and whether residual heart disease exists:
    • Without carditis: 5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer) (Option C ruled out)
    • With carditis but no residual disease: 10 years or until 21
    • With carditis + residual valvular disease: 10 years or until 40 years of age (or even lifelong)
  • The revised Jones criteria (2015) defines separate diagnostic thresholds for low-risk vs high-risk populations. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: It is tolerated well in pregnancy
Pulmonary edema usually occurs late in the course of disease
In atrial fibrillation, the opening snap disappears
The opening snap is not heard when the mitral valve is heavily calcified

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mitral stenosis (MS), most commonly caused by rheumatic fever, is characterized by obstruction to left ventricular inflow, leading to elevated left atrial pressure, pulmonary congestion, and eventually pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure.

A key auscultatory feature of MS is the opening snap, a high-frequency sound occurring shortly after the second heart sound (S2), due to the sudden tensing of the stenotic but still mobile mitral valve leaflets.However, when the valve becomes heavily calcified and immobile, the opening snap disappears.

Explanation of Other Options:

It is tolerated well in pregnancy (Option A): MS is poorly tolerated in pregnancy due to increased blood volume and cardiac output, which worsen pulmonary congestion and can precipitate acute pulmonary edema.

Pulmonary edema usually occurs late in the course of disease (Option B): In contrast to many valvular lesions, pulmonary edema can occur relatively early in MS due to left atrial pressure increase and backward transmission to the pulmonary circulation.

In atrial fibrillation, the opening snap disappears (Option C): AF abolishes presystolic accentuation of the diastolic murmur, but the opening snap remains as long as the valve is still mobile.

Key Takeaway:

Clinical Signs of Mitral Stenosis:

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a long-standing dental phobia finally visits a dentist for a severe toothache and is diagnosed with dental abscesses. She is brought to the emergency department by a relative due to high-grade fever. On auscultation, a diastolic murmur at the aortic area is noted. Which of the following findings is most suggestive of infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with a classic scenario of infective endocarditis (IE) following a dental source of bacteremia. The presence of a new diastolic murmur (likely aortic regurgitation) supports the diagnosis.

One of the peripheral signs of endocarditis is evidence of renal involvement due to immune complex deposition or septic emboli to the kidneys.

  • Microscopic hematuria, detected as blood on urine dipstick, is a common finding.
  • This reflects renal vasculitis or embolic infarction, both seen in subacute bacterial endocarditis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Roslyn's Spot (Option A): This is not a recognized sign in endocarditis. Likely a distractor or misnomer. Could be confused with Roth's spots, which are actual signs of IE.

Hepatomegaly (Option B): Though hepatomegaly may occur in right-sided heart failure, it is not a specific sign of endocarditis.

Pulmonary fibrosis (Option C): It is unrelated to infective endocarditis. Pulmonary complications in right-sided IE include septic pulmonary emboli, not fibrosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with chronic liver disease due to hepatitis C and suspected hepatocellular carcinoma experiences sudden loss of consciousness followed by right-sided hemiplegia. A cerebral angiogram shows lack of perfusion in the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory. Which of the following cardiac lesions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with a sudden focal neurological deficit due to ischemic stroke in the left MCA territory, on the background of debilitating chronic illness (hepatocellular carcinoma suspected). The underlying malignancy with hypercoagulability strongly points toward non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE), also known as marantic endocarditis.

NBTE is a form of non-infective endocarditis characterized by:

  • Sterile platelet-fibrin vegetations on cardiac valves (without associated inflammation or infection)
  • Occurs in patients with hypercoagulable states: advanced malignancy, sepsis, chronic wasting illness, or SLE/APS
  • Vegetations are friable and prone to embolization, especially to the brain, causing stroke
  • Valvular involvement order: mitral > aortic > tricuspid > pulmonary

Unlike infective endocarditis, NBTE does not cause significant valve destruction or systemic inflammatory signs (no fever, no leukocytosis, negative cultures).

Explanation of Other Options:

Acute rheumatic fever (Option A): Typically occurs in children and young adults post-streptococcal pharyngitis. Causes pancarditis with valvulitis, but rarely associated with embolic events or strokes. Also occurs in younger patients.

Left atrial myxoma (Option B): While it can cause embolic strokes, constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, arthralgia) and mitral valve obstruction signs are usually present. No mention of a mass on echocardiography. Also occurs in younger patients.

Libman-Sacks endocarditis (Option C): A non-infective endocarditis seen in SLE and antiphospholipid syndrome, not typically associated with malignancy. Valvular lesions are verrucous and usually affect both sides of the mitral and aortic valves. It typically affects younger women with autoimmune background.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has a predisposition to right-sided valvular pathologies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Right-sided valvular involvement is relatively rare compared to left-sided lesions, but certain conditions have a known predilection.

Carcinoid syndrome is classically associated with right-sided heart disease, especially involving the tricuspid and pulmonary valves.

  • Carcinoid tumors (often of the small intestine) secrete serotonin and other vasoactive substances.
  • When these substances bypass hepatic metabolism (as in metastatic liver disease), they reach the right side of the heart and cause endocardial fibrosis, particularly of the tricuspid and pulmonary valves.
  • This leads to tricuspid regurgitation and/or pulmonary stenosis.

Left-sided involvement is rare due to pulmonary monoamine oxidase activity that degrades serotonin before it reaches the left heart.

Important causes of predominantly right-sided valvular disease include:

  • Carcinoid syndrome
  • Ebstein anomaly (Tricuspid regurgitation)
  • Arrhythmogenic RV cardiomyopathy (TR)
  • RVMI (TR due to papillary muscle dysfunction)
  • Infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers (TR)

Explanation of Other Options:

Marfan syndrome (Option A): Associated with left-sided valvular abnormalities, especially aortic root dilatation, aortic regurgitation, and mitral valve prolapse.

SLE (Option C): Can cause Libman-Sacks endocarditis, which classically involves left-sided valves, particularly the mitral and aortic valves..

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option D): Rarely affects valves, but when it does, it tends to involve left-sided valvular fibrosis, mainly aortic regurgitation.
